You're right, there is no particular reason, but I'm not the owner of
the test case, just the guy who manages the campaign.

But I'll try soon your idea.

Thanks.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, James Abley <james.abley@g...> wrote:
> On Apr 11, 2005 8:36 PM, Soaring Eagle <comfortable.numb@g...> wrote:
> >  if you are using ANT's "exec" task to execute IE, set the "spawn"
> >  attribute = true.
> > 
> >  
> >  On Apr 11, 2005 11:15 AM, romut06 <softromu@h...> wrote:
> >  > 
> >  > 
> >  > Hello all,
> >  > I don't know where to post this question (Ant or JUnit), so I
decided
> >  > to post both, so I apologize in advance if I'm not in the right
forum.
> >  > 
> >  > Here is the problem :
> >  > I execute a test suite with a Ant task, in command line. One test
> >  > case, within this suite, opens an Internet Explorer window.
> >  > 
> >  > All the test cases are well executed. But at the end of the
campaign,
> >  > the Ant JUnit task never ends until this IE window is closed.
> >  > 
> >  > I'ev tried to put a specific task to close it and I know it
works well
> >  > but it is never executed as the JUnit task doesn't end because
of the
> >  > damned IE.
> >  > 
> >  > Any help will be greatly appreciated.
> >  > 
> 
> Is there a particular reason why you aren't cleaning up in the tests?
> e.g. if using Runtime.exec(), then call Process.destroy()?
> 
> James
